title.text: Predicting learner knowledge of individual words using machine learning

entities.text: Predicting learner knowledge of individual words

abstractContent.text: Predicting the knowledge of language learners is crucial for personalized interactions in any intelligent tutoring system for language learning.
This study adopts a machine learning approach to the task of predicting the knowledge of single words for individual learners of En-glish.

entities.text: predicting the knowledge of single words

abstractContent.text: We experiment with two machine learning models, neural networks and random forest, and with a set of learner-specific and word-specific features.
Both the models are trained for all the learners together.
However, since learner-specific features are used, the prediction is person-alized for every learner.
Both of the models achieve state-of-the-art results for the task of vocabulary prediction for English learners.

introductionContent.text: This study is part of a larger project which attempts to develop an intelligent personal assistant for English learning called Elia.
This assistant aims to support English learners in their informal contexts by reading or writing in English online through a browser plugin.

The browser plugin also allows the collection of data about the learner's interests, knowledge and learning patterns which are used to create additional opportunities for practice in a mobile app to enhance their vocabulary acquisition.
For the creation of personalized materials and personalized interaction, it is crucial to be able to automatically identify the learner's English knowledge.
Focusing on vocabulary knowledge first, the aim of this study is to create a model that would be able to predict the knowledge of single words for each learner individually.

This task was firstly formulated by as the vocabulary prediction task of which the goal is "to predict whether a learner knows a given word based on only a relatively small portion of his/her vocabulary" (p. 1374).

To tackle this problem, we adopt a machine learning approach where we engineer two sets of features, i.e., word-specific and learnerspecific features, using three data sources: COCA wordlist, MRC Psycholinguistic Database: Machine Usable Dictionary.
Version 2.00 and the English Vocabulary Knowledge Dataset (, the last which is also used for evaluation.

We experiment with two models, i.e., Random Forest model which uses learner-specific as an input to differentiate between learners, and Neural Network model which learns the learner-specific features from the word-specific features.
The rest of the paper is structured as follows.
The next section provides an overview of recent studies which are most relevant to this work (section 2).
In section 3, the dataset used to evaluate the model is introduced.
The features used for training and testing the models are described in section 4 and the two machine-learning models are described in section 5.
The last section summarizes the findings and suggest future directions (section 7).

datasetContent.text: We used the dataset provided by as it is the largest freely available dataset for vocabulary knowledge prediction.
It contains 11,999 English single words annotated by 16 learners of English accounting for 191,984 data points in total.
Most of the learners were native speakers of Japanese and attended the University of Tokyo.
The sampled words were taken from the SVL 12000 wordlist.
The learners were asked to indicate how well they knew the given words on a scale from 1 (I have never seen the word before) to 5 (I know the word's meaning).
Similarly, as in and, we assigned the words marked with 5 to "known" and the rest of the words marked with 1-4 to "unknown".
Since there can be a high variation between the knowledge of learners even of the same CEFR level), the goal is to make the knowledge prediction for each learner individually.
As rightly pointed out, "For example, a learner interested in music may know music-related words that even highlevel learners may not be familiar with" (p. 801).
Knowledge prediction which is learner-specific can be achieved by training an independent classifier for each learner separately (.
However, we train the model for all the learners together while keeping the prediction individualized.
This can be achieved by adding learner-specific features which would differentiate one learner from another.
